titlepage.titleproper:
Finding Aid for Volney H. Jones (1903-1982)
Papers, 1909-1979
titlepage.author:
Finding aid prepared by:
Christine Di Bella, 2003

did.abstract: Volney H. Jones was a leading ethnobotanist and served as Curator of Ethnology at the University of Michigan Museum of Anthropology from 1945 to 1969. The papers include correspondence with ethnobotanists and anthropologists, including Edward F. Castetter and Leslie A. White, administrative files, biographical information on anthropologists, teaching files for Jones' courses within the Department of Anthropology, and notes for unpublished textbooks on ethnobotany. The papers also include correspondence with Chase S. Osborn, Stellanova B. Osborn, and Milo M. Quaife concerning a project to establish a Friends of the Michigan Indian organization, and correspondence and reports from Ted Bank concerning the University of Michigan expeditions to the Aleutian Islands.

note.p: Sponsor: This finding aid is a product of a project supported by a grant awarded to the Bentley Historical Library and University of Michigan Museum of Anthropology in 2002 by the Division of Preservation and Access of the National Endowment for the Humanities, an independent federal agency.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The majority of the papers (donor no. 9273) were transferred by the University of Michigan Museum of Anthropology in 2003. One folder of previously processed correspondence (donor no. 4628) was integrated into the papers.

accessrestrict.p: The papers are open without restriction.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., Volney H. Jones Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Volney Hurt Jones was born on April 30, 1903 in Comanche, Texas. He received an Associate in Science certificate from North Texas Agricultural College in 1927 and a B.A. in agriculture from Texas A&M; University in 1929. He then enrolled in the graduate program in the Department of Biology at the University of New Mexico, studying ethnobotany under Edward Castetter. Jones was awarded a master's degree in 1931.

In 1931, Jones left New Mexico to take a position as a student assistant in the Ethnobotanical Laboratory at the University of Michigan's Museum of Anthropology, working under Melvin Gilmore. With Gilmore in poor health, Jones was called upon to take over much of the work of the lab almost from the earliest days of his appointment. When Gilmore died in 1940, Jones became head of the lab and the museum's ethnographic collections, though he did not receive the full official title of Curator of Ethnology until 1945. Jones also taught in the Department of Anthropology, and was particularly known for his popular course on Native Americans. He was named assistant professor in 1945 and associate professor in 1952. Jones held these positions until his retirement in 1969. Jones spent his entire professional career at Michigan, though he took a fifteen-month leave of absence from the university to work in rubber production in Haiti during World War II.

The Ethnobotanical Laboratory served as a central facility for researchers throughout the country to send ethnological and archaeological plant specimens for taxonomic identification and analysis. This work brought Jones in contact with many of the major figures in the fields of archaeology and ethnobotany, and the analyses from the over 350 specimen reports Jones authored were cited countless times in field reports and publications (though Jones did not always receive proper attribution).

Jones conceived of ethnobotany as much broader than simple identification and listing of plant samples, however. His ecological perspective on the field, which he defined as "the study of the interrelationships between primitive man and plants," was instilled in the many students he mentored over the years and shaped its future development. Jones was particularly notable for his pioneering work in paleoethnobotany; little recognized at the time they were done, Jones' studies of the biological remains of archaeological sites received renewed attention through the ongoing research of his former students, particularly Richard Yarnell, Vorsila Bohrer, and Richard Ford. In the late 1960s, Jones work at the University also involved consulting for a series of TV productions on Native Americans done in collaboration with the University of Michigan Law School and Television Center called Silent Heritage.

Jones' interest in Native Americans extended to his activities outside of the university as well. He served on several state commissions related to Native Americans in Michigan. He was also president of the Memorial to the American Indian Foundation, an organization formed in Ann Arbor in 1953 with an eye to erecting a sculpture in Gallup, New Mexico. Jones was also sometimes called upon to use his ethnobotanical knowledge in unusual ways, including serving as an expert witness from the 1940s to 1960s in the identification of marijuana plants for criminal cases.
Jones was married to Joyce Hedrick, a mycologist, from 1933 until her death in 1978. They had one son, Alan, born in 1937. Jones died on December 12, 1982 in Ann Arbor.

Additional biographical information about Volney Jones may be found in The Nature and Status of Ethnobotany, edited by Richard I. Ford, University of Michigan Museum of Anthropology Anthropological Papers no. 67, and "Volney Hurt Jones, 1930-1982" by C. Wesley Cowan, American Antiquity 53(3), 1988, pages 455-460.

For further information about the Ethnobotanical Laboratory, see "The Ethnobotanical Laboratory at the University of Michigan" by Melvin R. Gilmore, published as University of Michigan Museum of Anthropology Occasional Contributions, no. 1, as well as the Melvin R. Gilmore Papers, available at the Bentley Library.

scopecontent.p: The Volney H. Jones Papers include correspondence with ethnobotanists and anthropologists, including Edward F. Castetter and Leslie A. White, administrative files, biographical information on anthropologists, teaching files for Jones' courses within the Department of Anthropology, and notes for unpublished textbooks on ethnobotany. The papers also include correspondence with Chase S. Osborn, Stellanova B. Osborn, and Milo M. Quaife concerning a project to establish a Friends of the Michigan Indian organization, and correspondence and reports from Ted Bank concerning the University of Michigan expeditions to the Aleutian Islands. The Jones papers are comprised of eight series: Correspondence, Administrative Files, Biographies and Bibliographies, Teaching Files, Culture Areas and Ethnobotany Textbook Files, Hopi Research Files and Maize Research.

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series, 1930-1979 (2 linear feet), contains Jones' incoming and outgoing personal and professional correspondence, spanning from 1930 to 1979. The files are arranged alphabetically by correspondent, with files of miscellaneous correspondence at the end of each letter range.

Much of Jones' professional correspondence consists of discussions with other ethnobotanists and anthropologists about their laboratory research, field work, and analysis of organic samples. Jones' correspondence also serves as documentation of the beginnings of the field of paleoethnobotany. Correspondents of note include Edward Castetter (Jones' mentor at the University of New Mexico) and Leslie White. The files for Theodore (Ted) Bank include substantial information on a University of Michigan expedition to the Aleutians in the late 1940s. The dating of material from Sandia Cave is discussed in correspondence with Frank Hibben and Alex Krieger. Correspondence with Chase S. Osborn, Stellanova B. Osborn, and Milo M. Quaife concerning a project to establish a Friends of the Michigan Indian organization can be found in the Stellanova Osborn folder.

odd.p: (re: project to establish a Friends of the Michigan Indian organization)

did.unittitle: United States Government Printing Office Superintendent of Documents 1950

scopecontent.p: The Administrative Files series, 1953-1976 (0.5 linear feet), includes materials on a National Science Foundation grant, Jones' reviews of grant proposals, and administrative information related to the Museum of Anthropology.

did.unittitle: Memorial to the American Indian Foundation circa 1953
Prospectus on Moving, Reorganization and Rehabilitation of the Museum of Anthropology 1963
Regional Patterns in Pueblo Ethnobotany (National Science Foundation grant)
Report on Excavation of Jemez Cave 1965

scopecontent.p: The Biographies and Bibliographies series, bulk 1950s-1970s (1.25 linear feet), contains research materials, bibliographies, and biographical sketches for prominent anthropologists, with particular focus on ethnographers. While Jones compiled much of the supporting research himself from the 1950s to 1970s, many of the brief biographical sketches were written by students in Jones' Department of Anthropology course, Anthropology 557: Aboriginal Cultures of North America. The contents of the files range from a single citation to an obituary or published biography to a full biographical sketch. The most comprehensive of the sketches is one of James B. Griffin, written by Jones with handwritten amendments by Griffin. A few of the files include correspondence concerning Jones' research into a particular biographical subject.

did.unittitle: Benham, G.W. and Benham Exploring Expedition
Leighton, Alexander Hamilton and Dorothy Cross
List of Contributors to North American Ethnography

scopecontent.p: The Teaching Files series, bulk 1940s-1960s (1 linear foot), contains Jones' notes for his popular Aboriginal Cultures of North America course. The files includes Jones' course outlines, lecture notes, resource lists, and information compiled from secondary sources.

did.unittitle: Social and Political Forms and Functions

scopecontent.p: The Culture Areas series, bulk 1930s-1960s (1 linear foot), includes correspondence, notes, reports and citations related to various culture areas, with particular emphasis on plants. Much of the material is undated. While these were primarily reference files, they may have also been compiled in anticipation of authoring a textbook; Jones' order and arrangement of the files has been preserved. In addition to Jones' notes, drafts and outlines, the files include materials written or compiled by others, most notably Jones' mentor at Michigan, Melvin Gilmore. The section on the Plains Region, in particular, includes a number of Gilmore manuscripts and research materials. Jones' thesis on The Ethnobotany of the Isleta Indians can also be found within this series.

did.unittitle: Basin and Plateau Lecture Notes undated
Cree Medicines, Cowie Collection 14043-14060 Specimen Labels
Plant Materials from Sites in Canada 1931

odd.p: (notes from Edward S. Curtis by Gilmore)

odd.p: (notes on publication by W. C. Mills)

odd.p: (translation of article by Yakovleff and Herrera)

did.unittitle: Cultural Evolution as a Guide to Conquest Situations in South America 1963
Fauna and Flora of New Mexico Bibliography 1930-1931
The Ethnobotany of the Islet Indians, 1931 (Thesis)
Uses of Vegetal Pigments in Southwestern Pottery Paints

scopecontent.p: The Ethnobotany Textbook Files series, ca. 1945-1978 (0.75 linear feet), includes outlines, notes, drafts, and correspondence Jones compiled for a planned textbook on ethnobotany that he worked on from approximately 1945 to 1978 but never completed. Much of the material is undated. While a complete outline for the book is not found in the papers, Jones' order and arrangement of the files has been preserved to give a sense of the book's intended organization. As with the Culture Areas series, the files include material written or compiled by others, as well as by Jones.

did.unittitle: Basic Dependence of Man on Plants
Regions and Areas of North America
Nature and Origin of American Indian
Sources for Relation of Nature to Aboriginal Man

Maintenance of Prairie Conditions, Fire and Burning of Areas
Indian as a Factor in Plant Ecology
"Industrial Revolutions: Plants, Animals and Metals" (talk for WUOM radio) 1950

scopecontent.p: The Hopi Research Files series, ca. 1946 -- 1979, (0.5 linear feet) contains Volney Jones' correspondence, notes, and drafts on the history of Hopi reservations, their agents and administration, and expeditions to the Hopi people. A few photographs are included with the material.

did.unittitle: Tusayan; History of the Hopi Reservation 1850-1868, circa 1973

Thomas Keam; Government Agent to the Hopi Indians circa 1946-1950 (includes photos)

scopecontent.p: The Maize Research series, ca. 1950s -- 1978 (.1 linear feet) contains notes, drafts and publications about Jones' research on maize. The original arrangement of the research notes has been preserved

did.unittitle: Implication of hypothesis Theories of origin

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Additional biographical information about Volney Jones may be found in The Nature and Status of Ethnobotany, edited by Richard I. Ford, University of Michigan Museum of Anthropology Anthropological Papers no. 67, and "Volney Hurt Jones, 1930-1982" by C. Wesley Cowan, American Antiquity 53(3), 1988, pages 455-460.

For further information about the Ethnobotanical Laboratory, see "The Ethnobotanical Laboratory at the University of Michigan" by Melvin R. Gilmore, published as University of Michigan Museum of Anthropology Occasional Contributions, no. 1, as well as the Melvin R. Gilmore Papers, available at the Bentley Library.
